reviewText:
This is my

--------------->>> FAVORITE GAME OF ALL TIME <<<-----------------


Nothing else even comes close.

Absolutely gorgeous aesthetic, brilliant weapon design, fast-paced and satisfying action.

The BOTS in this game are GENUINELY INTELLIGENT!  And you can let their difficulty AUTO-ADJUST to fit EXACTLY at your skill level!  Bots should be standard in FPS imo.  ESPECIALLY MULTIPLAYER!  The player should NEVER be slave to what others want to play.  No players, no game in multiplayer gaming.  This is why I can still play Unreal Tournament when and how I want FOREVER!  And I have done exactly that so far.

Other than brilliant base gameplay, you have TONS of amazing mods for this game that are most often COMBINABLE AND CUSTOMIZABLE!  Tailor the experience to EXACTLY what you want!  I love it.

Fantastic map designs and creative weapons with MORE functionality than most shooters.  Two fire modes such as the Flak Cannon the fires a shotgun-blast of bouncing flak pellets OR an impact grenade that sprays some flak pellets on impact!  Maps in space and space stations, maps in medieval castles, so much variety in map choices and a few extremely unique ones!  Not to mention the variety of game modes which include team deathmatch, free-for-all, capture-the-flag, domination (point capture-and-hold mode), and best of all ASSAULT!

Assault game mode still belongs to Unreal Tournament.  This is the originator of that mode.  Accomplish one objective after another as a team and with such variety in maps and objectives to do it!  Like some brilliant combination of linear, singleplayer shooters and competitive multiplayer!  Cooperative and competitive at the same time!

I wish I could play this with friends to share the joy, but bots keep the experience alive forever!

reviewText:
A classic and still my favorite Unreal title, the original Unreal Tournament is a marvel of gaming excellence and is a benchmark other deathmatch shooters should strive to meet.  My first encounter with this game was on the PS2 and this GotY Steam version is only better, so if you've ever played this game you should definitely pick up this improved version.  The gameplay is just as good as it always has been and hasn't added any unnecessary complexity with the GotY tag.  Its simplicity is what makes it so awesome, and this version is a prime example of that.  I could add that Mod support is built into the engine, the settings are excellent for such an old title, the gameplay is crisp, clean, and fast, the sound quality is superb...I could go on and on, but there shouldn't be any reason to.  If you like Multiplayer / Arena FPS you know what Unreal Tournament is and if you haven't played the original you're missing out on the game that defined the genre.  There are Quake fans, there are Unreal fans, there are Halo fans, and even Call of Duty fans, but all gamers can appreciate the history of the medium and the titles that laid the groundwork for the future, and Unreal Tournament is undeniably THE title that brought these types of games to the forefront of gaming culture.

Pick it up for nostalgia's sake or even pick it up because it's still the best arena shooter created to date, Unreal Tournament is a game no FPS (or gaming) fan should lack and is just as fun today as when it hit the shelves all those years ago.

A+, do not miss.

Short version: 90%Unreal Tournament is one of the granddaddies of online team-based first-person shooters. It may have aged, but only in graphics, because the gameplay is still fast and exciting. And with its many game modes and high quality maps, itâ€™s a game that youâ€™ll never get bored of.

Long version:First-person shooters werenâ€™t always the on-rails, self-healing, cover-to-cover interactive movies they are today. This genre was a scene of highly competitive players who were constantly searching for the next game to test their limits. And in 1999 they got two of them, one being Unreal Tournament.

The game featured a bundle of innovative weapons with two fire modes; memorable map design that is copied even today; game modes that finally showed something innovative beyond the same old death matches; and finally, bots which may feel a little dumb and predictable today, but back then they were topped only by Half-Life 1.

UT may have been designed as a multiplayer game, but it is also enjoyable in single player. It has an actual campaign mode, where the â€œplotâ€ may be simple as a doornail (you play in a futuristic gladiator tournament) and most participants only have a single-paragraph story, but it is still enough to build the foundation of a world you can immerse yourself in and make you care about your team. Because despite the popularity of free-for-all death matches, this game is all about team play.

With the ever-increasing issues with the game engine (which was one of the best of its time) and the even more successful sequel, UT2004, UT â€™99 faded into obscurity, but if you ever want some really old-school FPS action, you can always rely on it.

Not playing UT 99 is a crime to gamers everywhere. UT 99 is arguably the most competitive multiplayer FPS game right next to Counter Strike. This is not a friendly game, don't expect to come in and start whoopin' â™¥â™¥â™¥ instantly...no, no...expect to come in and start getting YOUR â™¥â™¥â™¥ whooped instantly. Fast paced, gory, frag fest action at its finest. UT 99 is a game that is simple, you grab a gun (My personal fav being the Flak Cannon) and go find some meat!

The graphics of course may not be all that amazing, but graphics don't make a game, gameplay does and man does UT 99 offer that. With an arsenal of weaponry at your command and over a 100 maps, both by the dev, and the community, this is a game that I think will never get old, and the best part is after all these years, UT multiplayer is still going strong, just make sure you join a game with actual players and NOT bots. Trust me, you'll know if you are playing with bots or not. Single player is simple, you play in a tournament against bots, but personally, I skipped the campaign and went straight for the real deal multiplayer since I find fighting against bots...well boring. The soundtrack is foot-tappin awesomeness with fast techno tunes that go perfect with the sounds of rocket launchers and screams in the distance followed by the sound of body parts hitting the floor.

There is a ton of gore in this game so be prepared. I think UT can stand up to any game today and still win, yes, even Battlefield 4. I like UT a lot more than Quake III for many reasons. It seems what Quake III was flawed at, UT 99 was improved in. Now don't get me wrong, I like UT 2004, but there is something about UT 99 that I like a lot more than 2004. I'm not sure but 99 is just wayyy more fun and awesome for me that 2004 ever was. What else is there to say, it's fast, it's action-packed, it's gruesome, it's frantic, it's insane, it's intense, it's UT 99! And no need to worry about specs, any modern CPU can run this game perfectly smooth with no lag at all, believe me, I have a 1.0 GHZ processor laptop with AMD c-50 dual core. This is essential if you call yourself a PC gamer, and for the price of a book, you'd be silly NOT to buy this game! Don't let the difficulty of this game turn you off at first, UT is a game that is fun to play, but hard to master, it just takes time and patience to finally start getting into the swing of things and starting to get kills. So play UT 99 today! I'm sure you'll enjoy seeing your avatar die in an explosion of blood and limbs...:3

reviewText:
Unreal Tournament is another absolute classic and was a worthy contender against other online First Person Shooters such as Quake 3 Arena. The game was a spinoff title to Unreal. However unlike Unreal (which focused on single player), the game was instead an arena shooter with online multiplayer in mind. Despite this the game does have a single player campaign. The story for this game is as follows, 100 years has passed since the events within Unreal, a mining corporation known as Liandri is hosting a no-holds-barred fighting tournament. You have entered the Tournament to become the next champion, by competing in 4 different leagues which have their own game modes and unlock the fifth league in order to beat the previous tournament champion Xan. There really isnâ€™t much to the story and whilst there is more information within the single player campaign explaining the lore, character motivations and certain events within the Unreal Universe, it really doesnâ€™t add that much to the overall story.

The graphics werenâ€™t a huge improvement over Unreal, the reason for this was to increase performance when playing the game and maintain a high framerate with its fast pace gameplay. Despite this the game was still good looking for its time and the locations, level design, ascetics and environments in some maps is absolutely jaw dropping. A lot of the maps where set in different locations such as inside a spaceship, on an asteroid floating in space, inside an old medieval castle etc. It made each map feel more different and unique from each other. The soundtrack is also to the same quality as Unreal and is extremely good with some standouts like Foregone Destruction and Mechanism Eight.

In terms of gameplay you are given 6 different game modes, deathmatch which is a free for all, team deathmatch where two teams battle each other and the team with the most kills usually wins, capture the flag where two teams have to get the enemies team flag and bring it back to their own flag without the enemy taking theirs, domination where two teams have to take and keep control of key locations across the map, last man standing which is similar to deathmatch only players are given a full arsenal of weapons and have to stay alive as long as possible and assault which was a brand new game mode for its time. This is where players where broken up into two teams.(offensive and defensive)The offensive team have to complete key objectives in order to advance and win, the defenders have to prevent the other team from completing these objectives for as long as possible or until the timer ran out, both teams alternate and whichever team defends the longest wins.

The weapons in this game vary from familiar favourites such as the Flak Cannon and the Minigun and some new weapons like the Pulse Gun which replaces the Stinger. Each returning weapon has been given a minor tweak, such as having a faster rate of fire. The standout weapon among all of these is the newly added Redeemer a one use weapon which fires a rocket with a powerful area of effect annihilating anything within its radius. The botâ€™s in this game are extremely good and highly intelligent offering up a challenge when the player needs it. Overall Unreal Tournament is a fantastic game and is still fun to play today. The bots are a good enough challenge to play with and even though it isnâ€™t played as much online today you can still find a game with a few people to fill in the server or if youâ€™re setting up a LAN event any time soon then this game should be on your list.

reviewText:
Full Disclosure: I am a long-time consumer of the Unreal series, and a nearly life-long fan of both the Unreal series and Epic Games, the developer of said series. As such, I may be VERY biased, and my word might not be completely reliable, though I will try as usual to be as fair as possible.

Unreal Tournament is an Arena FPS whom is THE grandfather of the entire genre, of games which are entirely based upon combat in planned stages designed solely for combat, not story. It has fallen into obscurity since Unreal Tournament 2004's release, so allow me to try and show you how this game became such a staple of gaming.

These days, you've got games that run natively at 60fps, support resolutions for 4K monitors and ultra-wide monitors, and you've got games now which are nearly realistic for appearance. Unreal Tournament, came a bit late, but used it's engine well, Unreal Engine 1, which originated in the first Unreal game, which is an Engine that, even in the 90s, was the cutting edge of graphic fidelity and quality. It stands up even now, despite using polygons, lacking facial animations, but each weapon, and each character looks great even still. Levels still look gorgeous and cool, and almost falling into space still makes me very antsy even after 12 years later.

The game has only three modes. The Singleplayer Campaign, Multiplayer, and an offline skirmish-style mode titled Instant Action. The Campaign is of you, a new combatant in the newest deathsport known as the Unreal Tournament, where convicts have been turned into gladiators whom kill one another and win with the goal of becoming The Tournament Champion, effectively attaining a sort of celebrity-status. Multiplayer is smooth and reliable. There are no problems with the game itself that I've found, even with this re-release. Modes for it, are identical to Instant Action, only some maps function with people, as you don't need AI pathing with human players.
Instant Action's modes are Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Last Man Standing, Capture The Flag, Assault and Domination.
The only ones which aren't obvious and in other games, are Domination and Assault, so I will describe them.
Assault, is by far my favorite mode in virtually any game and it is a team-based mode with two teams. One team attacks a base, completing preset objectives and eventually aiming to complete them all, while the other team's objective is to stop the attacking team from completing objectives by any means.
Once the attacking team completes their objectives, they win the match, should they do all objectives and both teams switch sides, the defensive team becomes the new attacker, and vice-versa. At this point, the newly attacking team must match the completion time of the other team, or they will suffer a loss of the match. Though the sides switch even if the first attackers don't succeed, allowing both teams to attack and defend each match.
Domination, on the other hand, is a sort of variant of traditional King of The Hill gamemodes. Only there are multiple Hills, or Points, which either team (up to 4 teams, unlike other modes, save for TDM) must hold to win the match. Holding a point wil generate one score point for the team every 3 seconds or so, and holding more points will generate more.
It also has something no non-Unreal title has ever really adopted whole-heartedly; Mutators. Think of a mod, imagine how annoying it is that you can't just tick it on or off, or combine it with others witohut conflict for the most part. Mutators allow you to change parts of the game, like Low Gravity, and entirely different set of weapons, or powerful relics that change the game's strategies, or even classics like Volatile Ammo (ammo that is shot will discharge, resulting in hilarity from shooting ammo than the enemy) and Fatboy (Where your character model gets more fat" or just wider

reviewText:
There's not much to say about this game because it came out around the year 2000, and is old. But I grew up playing this, and I love it.

It's not that dynamic, and it certainly is not realistic (except for player/NPC damage), but the developers did try, and did a perfect job for a game of its time. That's why it won the Game of the Year award!

Now as old, cheezy, unrealistic, and lacks player freedom, this game is probably one of the funnest (yes, that's a word in my book) first-person shooter games I have ever played. If you know what the cheat codes of the game are, then use them whenever you feel like it. I do when I'm playing Practice Sessions!

I wouldn't recommend this game to people who either don't like first-person shooter games are are afraid of the game's quality not coming anywhere near 2015's standards, but I do if you like fast-paced games and you started playing video games in general around or before the time this game came out. By before, I mean 1970's. You know, Atari arcade games?

8 / 10 for me.

reviewText:
Since this is hands down my favorite video game of all time ever, I feel it deserves a very heartfelt review.

+One of the most iconic and unique weapon sets ever. each weapon has a different use depending on the situation, and each one has an alternate fire mode making them more versatile then your standard shotgun or assault rifle.

+A multitude of complex maps. In an age where we pay 60 bucks for a bare handful of maps (looking at you Battlefront), Its hard to belive that you can get a game that has nearly a hundred maps to play on for $10, each one unique and hard to memorize. This game contains some of the most iconic maps in video game history, including Curse, Deck 16, and the amazing Facing Worlds.

+Silky smooth controls. This game revolutionized the way movement was handled in first person shooters, and the movement mechanics still rival some of today's triple A titles. Thise game takes dodging bullets to a whole new level.

+mutators! bored with your run-of-the-mill deathmatch? apply the low grav mutator for some mid-air combat, or the insta-frag mutator for one-shot death carnage.

+Programmable and customizable AI. If youre feeling like a challenge, you can crank up the AI level to godlike, or if you're a filthy casual looking to blow off some steam, set the AI to average or novice and blow them to bits with your flak cannon.

-Graphics are of course not that great, but what do you expect from a game that came out in 1999?

-video settings can sometimes be a bit wonky. In order to get a resolution higher than 800x600, some messing around with the video drivers are required, as the default driver can't handle any more than that.

Why are you still reading? just get the game already.

reviewText:
Unreal Tournament was one of my favourite games growing up and it is still very playable today with a thriving community of veteran fans and newcomers alike. I was expecting the game to be extremely dated and bland but actually; it's as fast and fun as it ever was and is still absolutely brilliant with amazing memories.

No camping, no IED's, no grenade spamming, no quickoping, no mic spam, no fanboys, no microtransactions, no netcode woes and no commercial nonsense that plagues today's premium multiplayer games. UT represents the golden age of gaming and still played, enjoyed and loved by many now. It's fast, frantic and pure fun and at just a few quid; it's worth sacrificing a couple of beers for hours upon hours of nostalgia and enjoyment.

Ps; better than Titanfall;-)

reviewText:
This game is a great classic shooter. Out of all the Unreal Tournament games, this is probably my favorite game, and it isn't just nostalgia talking there either.

Unreal Tournament is pretty fast-paced. The guns are also different; you have your standard bullet-firing Enforcer and Sniper Rifle, and you have more exotic types like the plasma-firing Pulse Gun and the bio-sludge firing... Bio Gun.

The modding community behind this game is immense, and is still alive even today. Installing mods is as easy as grabbing the right UMOD, and installing it, or in the absence of a UMOD, you just drag-and-drop files to the right directory.

This game offers a story-line too, but as with other games in the series, it's mainly you vs bots on known multiplayer game types (CTF, Deathmatch, etc). Bots have various levels of difficulty, and make great practice.

Mutators are also a fun way to spice-up matches. Tired of the old weapons, and want a match with more insta-kill shenanigans? Throw on Instagib and get a modified Shock Rifle that delivers red beams of insta-death :p New mutators can also be delivered through mods.

A really popular recommended mod to get is ChaosUT, and I believe it even came with original Unreal Tournament GOTY discs back in the day (but is strangely absent from the Steam version).

The graphics may look a bit dated, but guess what? You can also fix that easily through mods :) Original GOTY discs also used to ship with ST3C textures to enhance the game's textures. These are nice and all, but the site UT Textures also offers even higher-quality textures for low-end (still better than the original ST3C textures), high-end, and extreme-end computers. Pair that with a newer renderer (like Marijn Kenti's D3D10 renderer, or the D3D9 or updated OpenGL renderer on Chris Dohnal's site), and you'll have yourself a very nice-looking classic! ENBSeries has nothing on those modifications.

Audio can also be updated. The easiest way to do this is to grab the updated multimedia package from Oldunreal's site. This allows for updated audio backends, like OpenAL and FMOD.

This game is a real treat, and it's really hard to find a reason on why not to buy it. If you've never played an Unreal Tournament game, haven't tried the classic version, or even if you want to re-visit a classic gem, get this.

If you've never played any UT or Quake, there's a good chance that this'll feel fresh as can be, and there's a good chance you'll never play anything like it again. While UT2004 (and 2003 and 3) are all great, the three are all their own entries, and this is probably the best. Nearly 15 years later, Unreal Tournament still remains an outstanding first-person shooter with some of the best FPS design (along with Q3A).

Nothing about it feels dated, and arguably first-person shooter game design as a whole has regressed from this and Q3A's high-level mental gaming and high skill ceiling shooters. Incredible pacing, maps designed to facilitate movement and area control, weapons with utility and balance, skillful gunplay all lead to the high-level mental games that really make the challenge and high skill ceiling the time.

Epic really struck gold with this in every way, and I'd highly suggest that everyone give this game a weekend to start that spark within them. It's not particularly casual, but the bots are still plenty fun (especially for non-pros) and if that and the excellent design aren't enough to sway you, there're plenty of mods and custom maps for it as well (though I think UT2004 really is the best of the series for mods).

These are nice and all, but the site UT Textures also offers even higher-quality textures for low-end (still better than the original ST3C textures), high-end, and extreme-end computers. Pair that with a newer renderer (like Marijn Kenti's D3D10 renderer, or the D3D9 or updated OpenGL renderer on Chris Dohnal's site), and you'll have yourself a very nice-looking classic! ENBSeries has nothing on those modifications.

Audio can also be updated. The easiest way to do this is to grab the updated multimedia package from Oldunreal's site. This allows for updated audio backends, like OpenAL and FMOD.

UT remains a classic multiplayer FPS that continues to influence game creators to this day. When it was released, Epic Games was competing with id Software for the FPS crown. Both companies decided to focus on multiplayer, with offline play supported by bots. While id's Quake 3: Arena went with stripped-down gameplay polished to a high sheen, Epic crammed in as many features and game modes as they could.

Besides the standard Deathmatch and CTF modes, UT introduced new modes like Assault that focused heavily on team-based action. Mutators that changed different aspects of the gameplay could be applied to any match and added lots of variety. Each weapon had a primary and secondary mode, which greatly increased the strategies available with each one. And while UT had the standard corridor-based Deathmatch maps, it also had huge open maps that were a sniper's dream, and many of them were larger than had ever been seen in a FPS at he time.

The classic gameplay still holds up, though most players gravitate to the game's successor, UT2K4, which took everything good about UT and cranked it up to 11 while adding many more unique features. If you want to see where modern shooters have their roots, UT is a great place to start playing.

How many good memories can a game give you? I'll answer you: countless. Even a FPS. But not any game, even less any FPS (called by some the dullest genre in game industry). But you need a GOOD game. A GOOD shooter. And Unreal Tournament is this good game.

Its original, ahead-of-its-time gameplay made it stand out of the rest. For me, it greatly surpassed even Quake 3 Arena. The grounded, dodge-based gameplay granted the player frantic action, and a lot of room for tactical play, that welcomed those who lacked the perfectionist twitch accuracy needed to play Quake. For example, my accuracy was never that good, but being able to avoid direct combat by rebounding flak shards or turning the floor into a minefield of goo made me less useless in this game, and that's why I love it.

UT's gameplay gives us something that Quake doesn't. In the same map, in Quake you could bunny hop or rocket jump all the way to one place and it just doesn't feel as nice as finding an actually creative way to reach the same place, as in UT. (Assuming there are user-made ports of some map that by default is exclusive to one of the games)

But even after you get tired of playing in all modes, all maps, with all mutators, there are user-made MODs. These are where the heart of the whole Unreal series is. The UnrealScript allowed players to easily create their own content for the game and publish it to be played by others, enriching the game, and extending its longevity. You're not allowed to utter the word obsolete" in UT (Unless you're Xan Kriegor)

Overall, the pros and cons;
PROS: enjoyable replayable experience, a wide range of unlockable levels and gaming styles (Eg. Team deathmatch, single deatchmatch, CTF etc), quite fast paced and refreshing.

But overall - HIGHLY recommendable.
